speech:
Identify Your Emotional Distress: 
Understand what’s causing your distress. Once you identify the source, you can work on addressing it.

Accept Your Emotional Experience: 
In times of stress, it’s often easy to spend a lot of time resisting the reality of your feelings. Accepting your emotional experience is the first step toward coping with it.

Keep an Emotional Toolkit on Hand:
 In a moment of distress, you may feel so overwhelmed that you temporarily forget your coping strategies. Having a toolkit of strategies can help.

Add in Gentle Movement:
 Physical activity, like a short walk or gentle yoga, can help reduce emotional distress.

Seek Professional Help:
 If your emotional distress is persistent or hard to manage, consider contacting a doctor or mental health professional.
